column2:
The recent Anti-Social Democrat information campaigns have proven successful!

While there were a few sectors of the population that proved less receptive to our campaigns, opinion polls in $CAPITAL$ and all across $COUNTRY$ have shown a marked decrease in party popularity across almost all demographic sectors and geographical regions.

Sociologists warn that these losses may prove short-lived if there is a deterioration of people's living conditions or a marked increase in popular dissent, but for now, we can rejoice in our well-deserved popularity.

Social scientists in $CAPITAL$ working in our information campaigns have asserted that the best way to target our information campaign within our population is to segment them by economic strata and focus on one of them: either upper-class, middle-class, or lower-class.

We may also attempt a generalized campaign and target the entire population to potentially increase our reach, although this comes with risks of backfiring in certain strata.

How should we target our campaign?

As employees of the State, $COUNTRY_ADJ$ bureaucrats, academics, and military personnel are a captive audience for our information campaigns.

We could focous our efforts to target one of these specific groups, thereby significantly decreasing ideological dissent within them. Alternatively, we could broadly target them in order to extend the overall reach of our campaigns.

Other than a possible research setback if we focus too much on academia, sociologists expect few negative effects from these focuses, if any.

$COUNTRY_ADJ$ academia is a prime target for our information campaigns, both to decrease socially-minded ideals within the sector and on the population at large through proper guidelines.

We could target educators directly with ideological goals, although this risks pushing out dissenters within academia.

We could target scientists and their research fields, at the risk of sidelining current projects for political reasons.

We could review the academic curriculum of our education system to include our desired political topics, although this could result in a temporary drop in education quality.

Or we could adopt a softer stance, and avoid potential undesirable effects.
Target Educators. [All Academics with >7 militancy or consciousness resign]

The Armed Forces of $COUNTRY$ are an ideal - and some say fundamental - target for our information campaigns, and we could further tailor our strategies to go after certain sections of our military.

We could target the Officer Corps with political education, although we may have to demote staunch dissenters and face some backlash from them.

We could target the enlisted soldiers, although similarly, we may have to discharge the most rebellious ones and it may affect our military readiness.

We could aim for both, at the cost of the aforementioned effects, or we could adopt a broad focus and a light touch to avoid the potential negative effects.
Target Officers. [All Officers with >7 militancy or consciousness are demoted]
Target Soldiers. [All Soldiers with >7 militancy or consciousness are discharged]
Target the Entire Military. [Both of the above]

Despite our best efforts, our information campaigns have been suffering from limited success. Leading sociologists in $CAPITAL$ have warned $COUNTRY_ADJ$ policymakers that high levels of ideological consciousness and political radicalization are to blame, and advise to refocus some of our efforts into lowering them.

We could focus our efforts against political consciousness or against militant dissent, at the cost of our main information efforts and likely backsliding.

We could aim for both at the same time, at the risk of hindering our ideological objectives in the short term, but increasing our communication success in the medium term.

Lastly, we could focus on our original campaigns and minimize their disruptions, but this would only net us minor reductions of miltancy and consciousness. Either way, it's not a straightforward choice.

While our information campaign has been focused for internal $COUNTRY_ADJ$ consumption, several diplomats and statesmen from across the world have admired our efforts, even from nations who nominally would support Social Democracy.

International Relations experts in $CAPITAL$ consider this a magnificent opportunity to spread our influence or, at the very least, further our diplomatic goals. We could shape the narrative to focus on $COUNTRY_ADJ$ prestigious achievements and feats, or insist in our good will and positive relations with our neighbors. Some even suggest we could use these tools to shape the narrative around... unfortunate past events.

A small but determined group of sociologists, however, view this as an unimportant distraction from the true domestic objectives of our campaigns, and wish to refocus on internal matters.

The surge in Social Democratic ideals have led to some in $CAPITAL$ to consider expanding our campaigns to target broader ideological coalitions, rather than just the Social Democrats themselves.

We could target their closest allies: the Socialists, in exchange for some decrease in our main efforts. We could aim against the broader coalition, targeting the Communists as well, or even target the entire wing, including the Greens.

Alternatively, we could focus in our own ideological lines, at the cost of reduced overall reach and greater political awareness due to these coalitions.

For better or worse, the anti-Social Democrat information campaign in $COUNTRY$ has failed to achieve its desired results.

Perhaps the government was too fractured to paint a cohesive image to the public. Perhaps dissent was too high, and the common folk were reluctanct to indulge in partisan messages. Or, we simply did not have the proper know-how and tools to run an effective information campaign given our circumstances.

In any case, the citizenship has been left, if not more ideologically aligned, at least more politically engaged. We could try with a new campaign, although sociologists from $CAPITAL$ are pessimistic on our odds unlesss we solve the underlying issues first.

Despite our best efforts, the anti-Social Democrat information campaign in $COUNTRY$ has not only failed, but it has managed to attract a significant portion of our population to their ideals!

Sociologists in $CAPITAL$ pin the blame on the charged political atmosphere in $COUNTRY$, that has made our nation incredibly polarized in all sorts of topics, and extremely cynical of our information efforts. They advise that this can be curtailed through reducing dissent and improving our sociological and psychological studies to better reach the masses.

Although most agree it is only a temporary setback, it may take years to fully restore our political popularity in the nation.
